intro: Microrhamnus franguloides, commonly known as the narrowleaf buckthorn, is a shrub native to the western United States. It is characterized by its small, dark green leaves and reddish bark that becomes fissured with age. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers in clusters, followed by black, egg-shaped berries that are a food source for birds and small mammals. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in chaparral and woodland habitats. Microrhamnus franguloides is a member of the Rutaceae family, which includes citrus and other flowering plants.
